awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Advanced Micro Vibration Energy Harvesters for Energy-Autonomous Internet of Things
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to address the power problem, which significantly limits the deployment and functionality of next generation wireless sensors and internet-of-things (IoT) nodes and inhibits their impact on energy and efficiency savings in the most needed areas of smart manufacturing, smart transportation, and building automation. Most high-impact IoT applications typically require miniaturization and placement of wireless sensor nodes in hard-to-service locations in vast numbers, where the battery replacement or electrical wiring is not practical or too costly. This research and development effort will explore the fundamental and technological limits of vibration energy harvesters, and development of novel micro vibration energy harvesters with high power density, multi-axis operation capability, and wider frequency bandwidth. These low-cost micro vibration energy harvesters aim to enable energy-autonomous wireless sensor nodes that will open up new markets and high-impact applications for self-powered IoT nodes, achieve energy savings and increased efficiency in multiple industries due to enabled continuous data gathering, reduce the ecological footprint of millions of wasted toxic batteries, and significantly decrease the maintenance cost of industrial IoT networks. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to develop a millimeter-scale vibration energy harvester that can provide high power density, multi-axis operation capability and sufficiently wide operation bandwidth, as a maintenance-free and low-cost renewable power source for next-generation industrial IoT nodes. Existing vibration energy harvesters have limited practical applications in real life, as they suffer from large size, high-cost, low power density, high operation frequency, and extremely narrow frequency bandwidths. Moreover, commercial harvesters can only operate at a single vibrational axis and cannot harvest efficiently from complex three-dimensional vibration profiles found in real-life applications. This SBIR Phase I project will focus on novel device architectures to achieve a high-power density in a highly compact device volume and to harvest energy efficiently from low-amplitude vibrations along any spatial directions. In addition, new device architectures will be investigated to obtain further improved performance and additional functionalities. Analytical simulations and finite element analysis will be performed to optimize device performance. Prototypes will be fabricated via a proprietary advanced micro manufacturing method to obtain high-quality piezoelectric thin films on silicon wafers. Fabricated harvester prototypes will be tested at conditions simulating target industrial applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The highest impact of IoT is expected to occur in smart manufacturing and transportation through autonomous monitoring of machines, vehicles, and infrastructures via a vast network of wireless IoT nodes performing autonomous control and predictive maintenance. However, the need for maintenance-free and low-cost power over a long-term unattended use is one of the greatest challenges to large-scale global deployment of industrial IoT. Tethering an IoT node to a power outlet or using a finite-lifetime battery not only escalates the ownership cost significantly, but also prohibits the cutting-edge applications, where an IoT node needs to be miniaturized or placed in hard-to-access locations. 

ActiveMEMS was awarded with a SBIR Award by the National Science Foundation to develop and investigate multi-axis energy harvester architectures to generate electricity from environmental mechanical vibration with increased efficiency, improved power output, and widened operation bandwidth at MEMS scale. During the course of this award, operation conditions and vibration profile from different application areas, such as industrial monitoring and vehicle instrumentation, were obtained and analyzed with field data. Multi-physics finite element analysis was performed to study and optimize a micro energy harvester and obtain maximum power output from multiple-axes with the modal frequencies in the frequency range of target applications. Prototypes of the designed micro harvester were microfabricated, and experimental characterizations were performed to confirm a high-power density and vibration sensitivity in all three axes and a compact form factor. The experimental results of the microfabricated vibration harvester were benchmarked against existing similar products in the market, and demonstrated superior performance in power density, vibration sensitivity, frequency bandwidth, and operation temperature. 

The result of this project is expected to enable miniaturized self-powered IoT devices, open up new industrial IoT applications with uninterrupted maintenance-free operation, and provide continuous data gathering and optimized resource management in smart manufacturing and transportation. In addition to decreasing the maintenance cost of IoT networks, the developed energy harvesting technology can reduce the ecological footprint of batteries, and minimize the cost and waste of resources as well as the harsh chemicals in battery disposal/recycling.
